King Lear is no exception: I go some way in providing a theological notation to a crucial moment of Lear’s descent into madness, the fracturing of his blank verse into prose. Is the storm on the heath a representation of the turmoil of his mind? Or is it a theophany, the manifestation of divine displeasure at human foolishness? Finding between the verse and the prose the theological tradition of Christianity will allow us to negotiate this question and to understand a little more clearly the peculiar wisdom of poetry for Christianity.' creationdate: - '2017' creatorcontrib: - Hackett, William recordtype: - article sourceid: - DOA recordid: - eNqtULtOw0AQtBBIREDDF5xEh2LYu7N9vjKKeFhEUATq03JeBwfjC2enoMs_0ELLh-VLcAgCSpDYZndHs6OdCYJ9DkdSajj2VKUQA2i-EfQEKBXyKIo2f8zbwV7TTKGrFEBJ3Quq5eJlUOfs-s7N-wyrKhzf4X1ZTzpkXufkl4u35eJ10K3kKjcpLVbs0rXYlq5mrWOjsqaG8eXiWabMFexidTsi9H02sC3LsqzPxpZq6sbdYKvAqqG9z74TZKcn18PzMHc4NTNfPqB_Mg5L8wE4PzHo29JWZEDaFDAGoUQRkVV4i5QQIOoiLVBHcic4XGtZ75rGU_Glx8Gs4jHf8XTkgzV55t3jnJrWTN3c191PhmsOCUSKq451s2aNrs6y4WAUWimgDYXUmKLWVulOzCZJjIXmaaK1LnLSQhHZW53kFPFY2JyTlImgRAgLqbCxkP9r-3dO_hDOOzFVtEc scope: - AAYXX - CITATION - 3V. - 4U- - 7XB - 88H - 8FK - 8G5 - ABUWG - AFKRA - AZQEC - BENPR - CCPQU - DWQXO - GNUQQ - GUQSH - M2N - M2O - MBDVC - PIMPY - PQEST - PQQKQ - PQUKI - PRINS - Q9U - DOA creator: - Hackett, William title: - "“And Thou, all-Shaking Thunder…”A Theological Notation to Lines 1–38 of King Lear, Act III, Scene II" - Religions (Basel, Switzerland ) subject: - Christianity - Drama - Foolishness - Hans Blumenberg - Literary criticism - Literary history - Poetry - Poetry and Religion - Shakespeare and Theology - Shakespeare, William (1564-1616) - Theology - Wrath issn: - 2077-1444 - 2077-1444 fulltext: - 'true' general: - MDPI AG startdate: - '20170511' enddate: - '20170511' delivery: delcategory: - Remote Search Resource fulltext: - fulltext display: description: - 'In the dramas of Shakespeare, the madman and the fool speak in prose; wisdom and sanity are properly poeticised.
